text:
Q: I am confused, when to use tensorflow and pytorch A:

If you want to train a model, just use pytorch; it is the most popular library in deep learning.

If you want to deploy a model on a device such as deploying YOLO, try tensorrt or onnxruntime, these are more suitable for network inference.

Q: Why 2 tables bucketed by col1 and joined by (col1, col2) are shuffled? A:

Q : Why does this happen? Logically, if data is bucketed by col1, then rows with same col1 are in the same bucket, which means rows with same (col1, col2) are also in the same bucket.

Because Spark does not consider the buckets usable for the join since the tables are bucketed only on col1 but the join requires (col1, col2), so it inserts a shuffle to guarantee correct partitioning for the SortMergeJoin.

Q: How do select ref OID without table object join when type is ref with OID? A:

I dont understand what do you mean? If I should do any changes in my select please let me know. As I said, I wanted to know that if it is possible to have a ref rowid the same as other fields in the mentioned select without adding a table object join, which is t_tab_object here because ref is with rowid.

Q: SwiftUI-Button: Complete VStack clickable A:

You can add the .buttonStyle(.borderless) modifier to your button; this tells SwiftUI to constrain the button's tap target to just the button's actual frame rather than allowing the List row's gesture to take over.

Alternatively, .buttonStyle(.plain) can work, but .borderless is generally more reliable for this specific issue within Lists.

Ultimately, the fix involves either restructuring the view hierarchy or using .buttonStyle(.borderless) to isolate the button's tap target.

Q: How to get sane definition of uint32_t when using newlib? A:

C standard does not specify which standard integer type uint32_t should alias to, or if it should alias to any standard type at all. Your assumption that uint32_t should be unsigned int is just that - an assumption. It holds true for gcc/glibc combo; it doesn't for gcc/newlib combo because newlib maps uint32_t to __UINT32_TYPE__ which is defined in gcc to be unsigned long for 32-bit newlib targets. You'd need to patch gcc or newlib to make it into int.

This is a very common mistake to make (e.g. I very recently saw llvm build issue because of their usage of std::max on int32_t and int arguments) but mistake nonetheless. Can't assume uint32_t is unsigned int, can't assume it can be losslessly converted to unsigned int (after all, int can be 16 bit), gotta use correct format specifiers. Like said in the comment, PRIx32 macro is the only correct specifier for uint32_t. Alternatively one could do an explicit conversion to unsigned long, and print that converted value instead.

EDIT: You are insistant you may use '%x' because uint and uint32_t happens to be same width on your particular target. Well no you may not, not according to C standard. '%x' is defined as:

The unsigned int argument is converted to ... unsigned hexadecimal notation (x or X)

%x implies unsigned int and nothing else. This is a singular type you may use. Anything else is not a valid C code; it might work on your target but it won't on another. Details of your particular target are not important. Like @user2357112 said uint32_t is no different from long in this matter - that's NOT unsigned int and can't be used. The compiler correctly warns you that your code is not a standard-compliant C code.

If you want to use '%x' with uint32_t... well, its your code. Use it. You could patch gcc/newlib to make uint32_t alias to unsigned int (I think this is the place to do it - https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/master/gcc/config/newlib-stdint.h#L38), or you could just switch that warning off. Regardless of that your code would still be violating C standard (though it would work just fine as long as you stick to common 32/64 targets).

Q: Not able to set cookie in hono A:

working with cookies locally is a little nuanced, mainly because of how security features in fetch, HTTP, and browsers overlap. this answer covers handling cors + cookies in some depth: https://stackoverflow.com/a/46412839/11245505. it's worth a read.

as far as i can tell, your code is fine though. which browser(s) are you using? i tested equivalent code in firefox and the cookie was set and read successfully, but only after i allowed cross-site scripts for http://localhost:3000 in settings.

tl;dr - the issue is probably your browser settings. many modern browsers block cross-site cookies by default, but allow you to configure exceptions.

the following example was tested with hono@4.10.5 and bun@1.3.5, but should work almost anywhere hono runs:

the cors middleware credentials option sets the required Access-Control-Allow-Credentials header. be sure to use specific origins, not wildcard (*):

app.use('*', cors({
  origin: 'http://localhost:3000',
  credentials: true,
}))

your cookie code is also correct, though secure should be dynamic based on some env flag:

setCookie(c, 'hello', 'world', {
  httpOnly: true,
  secure: process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production', // <--       
  sameSite: 'Lax',      
  path: '/',
  maxAge: 60 * 60 * 24, 
})

setting sameSite to none requires that secure is true, which will block the browser from reading the cookie from localhost.

your axios code also seems right. below is the fetch version, but withCredentials should do the same thing. this ensures that cookies are included in cross-site requests.

await fetch('http://localhost:8000', {
  credentials: 'include',
}).then((res) => res.json())

Q: Scala Spark RDD error : java.lang.ClassCastException: cannot assign instance of java.lang.invoke.SerializedLambda A:

simply jar is missing we need to supply explicitly either by spark-submit like this

spark-submit \
  --class your.main.Class \
  --master spark://centos-master:7077 \
  --jars yourdependency1.jar,yourdependency2.jar \
  your-application.jar

or by your code above code

import org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession

object MyApp {
  def main(args: Array[String]): Unit = {
    val spark = SparkSession.builder()
      .master("spark://centos-master:7077")
      .appName("spark-api")
      .getOrCreate()

    // Add JAR dynamically
    spark.sparkContext.addJar("yourdependency1.jar")
    spark.sparkContext.addJar("yourdependency2.jar")

    // Now your RDD/DataFrame operations can use classes in these JARs
    val rdd = spark.sparkContext.parallelize(Seq(1,2,3))
    println(rdd.collect().mkString(","))
  }
}
